page.title: List of companions in Doctor Who spin-offs

rev.comment: rm fair use images; see talk
rev.diff:
Line 5: Line 5:
==A==
==A==
===Antimony===
===Antimony===
â
[[Image:Antimony_android.jpg|thumb|120px|Antimony]]
 
'''Antimony''' was a companion of the [[Seventh Doctor]] and appeared in the [[webcast]] story ''[[Death Comes to Time]]'' by Colin Meek (widely understood to be a pseudonym for [[Dan Freedman]]). At the start of the story, the listener was not aware of the circumstances of his and the Doctor's meeting. Antimony appeared to be a young humanoid male who was slightly unworldly and naive, for example believing there were still [[Allosaurus]]es roaming the Earth.
'''Antimony''' was a companion of the [[Seventh Doctor]] and appeared in the [[webcast]] story ''[[Death Comes to Time]]'' by Colin Meek (widely understood to be a pseudonym for [[Dan Freedman]]). At the start of the story, the listener was not aware of the circumstances of his and the Doctor's meeting. Antimony appeared to be a young humanoid male who was slightly unworldly and naive, for example believing there were still [[Allosaurus]]es roaming the Earth.
Line 37: Line 36:
===Catherine Broome===
===Catherine Broome===
â
[[Image:Catherine Broome.jpg|right|thumb|120px|Cat]]
 
'''Catherine "Cat" Broome''' was a companion of the [[Seventh Doctor]] from the [[Telos Doctor Who novellas|Telos novella]] ''[[Companion Piece]]'' by [[Robert Perry]] and [[Mike Tucker]]. The Doctor and Cat are already travelling together at the start of the novella. Needing mercury links for the [[TARDIS]], they tried to steal some from the Wierdarbi, a race of cybernetically enhanced insects. When cornered by the Wierdarbi, Cat defeated them by releasing a swarm of prototype robots built by the Doctor.
'''Catherine "Cat" Broome''' was a companion of the [[Seventh Doctor]] from the [[Telos Doctor Who novellas|Telos novella]] ''[[Companion Piece]]'' by [[Robert Perry]] and [[Mike Tucker]]. The Doctor and Cat are already travelling together at the start of the novella. Needing mercury links for the [[TARDIS]], they tried to steal some from the Wierdarbi, a race of cybernetically enhanced insects. When cornered by the Wierdarbi, Cat defeated them by releasing a swarm of prototype robots built by the Doctor.
Line 49: Line 47:
===Tom Campbell===
===Tom Campbell===
â
[[Image:Tom-campbell.JPG|right|thumb|100px|Tom Campbell]]
 
Special Constable '''Tom Campbell''' (portrayed by [[Bernard Cribbins]] who later played [[Wilfred Mott]] in the revived television series in 2007-2008) travelled with "[[Dr. Who (Dalek films)|Doctor Who]]" in the feature film ''[[Daleks - Invasion Earth 2150 AD]]''. His role replaced that of [[Ian Chesterton]] in the television serial ''[[The Dalek Invasion of Earth]]'', on which the film was based.
Special Constable '''Tom Campbell''' (portrayed by [[Bernard Cribbins]] who later played [[Wilfred Mott]] in the revived television series in 2007-2008) travelled with "[[Dr. Who (Dalek films)|Doctor Who]]" in the feature film ''[[Daleks - Invasion Earth 2150 AD]]''. His role replaced that of [[Ian Chesterton]] in the television serial ''[[The Dalek Invasion of Earth]]'', on which the film was based.
Line 56: Line 53:
===Alison Cheney===
===Alison Cheney===
â
[[Image:Alisoncheney.jpg|right|thumb|120px|Alison]]
 
'''Alison Cheney''' was a companion of the "unofficial" [[Shalka Doctor|Ninth Doctor]] who appeared in the [[Macromedia Flash|flash]]-animated serial ''[[Scream of the Shalka]]'' by [[Paul Cornell]] and the short story [http://www.bbc.co.uk/cult/vampires/newstory/scottwright.shtml ''The Feast of the Stone''] by [[Cavan Scott]] and [[Mark Wright (writer)|Mark Wright]]. Her voice was provided by [[Sophie Okonedo]], who was also the visual model for the character, animated by [[Cosgrove Hall Films|Cosgrove Hall]].
'''Alison Cheney''' was a companion of the "unofficial" [[Shalka Doctor|Ninth Doctor]] who appeared in the [[Macromedia Flash|flash]]-animated serial ''[[Scream of the Shalka]]'' by [[Paul Cornell]] and the short story [http://www.bbc.co.uk/cult/vampires/newstory/scottwright.shtml ''The Feast of the Stone''] by [[Cavan Scott]] and [[Mark Wright (writer)|Mark Wright]]. Her voice was provided by [[Sophie Okonedo]], who was also the visual model for the character, animated by [[Cosgrove Hall Films|Cosgrove Hall]].
Line 74: Line 70:
===Crystal===
===Crystal===
â
[[Image:Crystal drwhoua.PNG|right|thumb|100px|Crystal]]
 
'''Crystal''', a nightclub singer, appeared in the stage play ''[[Doctor Who - The Ultimate Adventure]]'', written by [[Terrance Dicks]]. She was portrayed by [[Rebecca Thornhill]].
'''Crystal''', a nightclub singer, appeared in the stage play ''[[Doctor Who - The Ultimate Adventure]]'', written by [[Terrance Dicks]]. She was portrayed by [[Rebecca Thornhill]].
Line 118: Line 113:
===Emma===
===Emma===
â
[[Image:Emma (Doctor Who companion).jpg|right|thumb|120px|Emma]]
 
'''Emma''' was the companion of the Ninth Doctor portrayed by [[Rowan Atkinson]] in the [[1999]] spoof charity serial ''[[Doctor Who and the Curse of Fatal Death]]'' written by [[Steven Moffat]] and produced for the charity ''[[Comic Relief (charity)|Comic Relief]]''. She was portrayed by [[Julia Sawalha]], who had previously auditioned for the role of [[Ace (Doctor Who)|Ace]].
'''Emma''' was the companion of the Ninth Doctor portrayed by [[Rowan Atkinson]] in the [[1999]] spoof charity serial ''[[Doctor Who and the Curse of Fatal Death]]'' written by [[Steven Moffat]] and produced for the charity ''[[Comic Relief (charity)|Comic Relief]]''. She was portrayed by [[Julia Sawalha]], who had previously auditioned for the role of [[Ace (Doctor Who)|Ace]].
Line 147: Line 141:
===Gus Goodman===
===Gus Goodman===
â
[[Image:Gusgoodman.jpg|thumb|120px|Gus]]
 
'''Angus Goodman''', or simply '''Gus''', was a companion of the [[Fifth Doctor]] in the ''[[Doctor Who Magazine|Doctor Who Monthly]]'' comic strips. He first appeared in the story ''Lunar Lagoon'' (DWM #76-#77), although he did not meet the Doctor until the start of the next story, ''4-Dimensional Vistas'' (DWM#78-#83). Gus's first appearances were written by [[Steve Parkhouse]] and illustrated by [[Mick Austin]]; he was later drawn by [[Steve Dillon]].
'''Angus Goodman''', or simply '''Gus''', was a companion of the [[Fifth Doctor]] in the ''[[Doctor Who Magazine|Doctor Who Monthly]]'' comic strips. He first appeared in the story ''Lunar Lagoon'' (DWM #76-#77), although he did not meet the Doctor until the start of the next story, ''4-Dimensional Vistas'' (DWM#78-#83). Gus's first appearances were written by [[Steve Parkhouse]] and illustrated by [[Mick Austin]]; he was later drawn by [[Steve Dillon]].
Line 181: Line 174:
==J==
==J==
===Jason===
===Jason===
â
[[Image:Jason drwho ultimateadv.PNG|right|thumb|150px|Jason (Graeme Smith)]]
 
'''Jason''', a young nobleman from [[French Revolution|Revolutionary France]], appeared in the stage play ''[[Doctor Who - The Ultimate Adventure]]'', written by [[Terrance Dicks]].
'''Jason''', a young nobleman from [[French Revolution|Revolutionary France]], appeared in the stage play ''[[Doctor Who - The Ultimate Adventure]]'', written by [[Terrance Dicks]].
Line 218: Line 210:
===Sir Justin===
===Sir Justin===
â
[[Image:Sirjustin.jpg|thumb|120px|Sir Justin]]
 
'''Sir Justin''', a medieval knight, accompanied the [[Fifth Doctor]] in the ''[[Doctor Who Magazine|Doctor Who Monthly]]'' comic strip story ''The Tides of Time'' (DWM#61-#67), written by [[Steve Parkhouse]] and illustrated by [[Dave Gibbons]].
'''Sir Justin''', a medieval knight, accompanied the [[Fifth Doctor]] in the ''[[Doctor Who Magazine|Doctor Who Monthly]]'' comic strip story ''The Tides of Time'' (DWM#61-#67), written by [[Steve Parkhouse]] and illustrated by [[Dave Gibbons]].
Line 284: Line 275:
==O==
==O==
===Olla===
===Olla===
â
[[Image:Olla.jpg|thumb|120px|right|Olla]]
 
'''Olla''' was very briefly a companion of the [[Seventh Doctor]] in the ''[[Doctor Who Magazine]]'' comic strips. Olla was a Dreilyn, a heat [[vampire]] whose race drew sustenance from draining the heat from other beings, although never enough to kill. She first met the Doctor and [[Frobisher (Doctor Who)|Frobisher]] on A-Lux in the story ''A Cold Day in Hell'' (DWM#130-#133), written by Simon Furman and drawn by [[John Ridgway (comic artist)|John Ridgway]]. A-Lux was a resort planet which the [[Ice Warrior]]s were planning to freeze and turn into a new [[Mars (Doctor Who)|Mars]]. Olla helped the Doctor and Frobisher defeat the Ice Warriors, and when Frobisher elected to stay behind, the Doctor took her on board as his newest companion. The Doctor, however, was mildly disturbed by the way Olla kept waiting on him hand and foot.
'''Olla''' was very briefly a companion of the [[Seventh Doctor]] in the ''[[Doctor Who Magazine]]'' comic strips. Olla was a Dreilyn, a heat [[vampire]] whose race drew sustenance from draining the heat from other beings, although never enough to kill. She first met the Doctor and [[Frobisher (Doctor Who)|Frobisher]] on A-Lux in the story ''A Cold Day in Hell'' (DWM#130-#133), written by Simon Furman and drawn by [[John Ridgway (comic artist)|John Ridgway]]. A-Lux was a resort planet which the [[Ice Warrior]]s were planning to freeze and turn into a new [[Mars (Doctor Who)|Mars]]. Olla helped the Doctor and Frobisher defeat the Ice Warriors, and when Frobisher elected to stay behind, the Doctor took her on board as his newest companion. The Doctor, however, was mildly disturbed by the way Olla kept waiting on him hand and foot.
Line 364: Line 354:
===Wolsey===
===Wolsey===
â
[[Image:Wolsey the Cat.jpg|right|thumb|120px|Wolsey the Cat, in a humanoid form from ''Oh No It Isn't!'']]
 
'''Wolsey''' (named for [[Thomas Cardinal Wolsey|Cardinal Wolsey]]) was a cat given to the [[Seventh Doctor]] by Joan in the novel ''[[Human Nature (Doctor Who novel)|Human Nature]]'' by [[Paul Cornell]]. Wolsey travelled in the TARDIS until the events of ''[[The Dying Days]]'' by [[Lance Parkin]]. The [[Eighth Doctor]] then gave Wolsey to [[Bernice Summerfield]], and the cat remained with her for the remainder of the [[Virgin New Adventures|New Adventures]]. Wolsey also appeared in some of the ''Bernice Summerfield'' audio dramas and books from [[Big Finish Productions]].
'''Wolsey''' (named for [[Thomas Cardinal Wolsey|Cardinal Wolsey]]) was a cat given to the [[Seventh Doctor]] by Joan in the novel ''[[Human Nature (Doctor Who novel)|Human Nature]]'' by [[Paul Cornell]]. Wolsey travelled in the TARDIS until the events of ''[[The Dying Days]]'' by [[Lance Parkin]]. The [[Eighth Doctor]] then gave Wolsey to [[Bernice Summerfield]], and the cat remained with her for the remainder of the [[Virgin New Adventures|New Adventures]]. Wolsey also appeared in some of the ''Bernice Summerfield'' audio dramas and books from [[Big Finish Productions]].
